All international travellers arriving in all ports of entry into Tonga will be required to complete a Traveller’s Arrival Health Declaration Card, and provide it to the relevant authorities.

International travellers, travelling from or through China, must spend at least 14 days self-quarantine at last port that is free of COVID-19 and must undergo medical clearance within 3 days prior to final route to Tonga in order to be granted entry to the country. Failure to do so can resulted in denial of entry. 

Exceptions for Tongan citizens, permanent residents, their immediate family members as well as air crew who used appropriate PPE equipment.
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Effective 23 March, Tonga closes its borders, including international flights, cruise ships and yachts for 14 days. The restriction affects Fiji Airways, Air New Zealand, Virgin Australia, and Talofa Airways flights.

Tonga extends incoming flight bans for Fiji Airways, Air New Zealand, and Talofa Airways until September 12, 2020. UPDATE: The restriction no longer effects Virgin Australia airlines, but still effects Fiji Airways, Air New Zealand, and Talofa Airways flights. The original restriction was set to last until April 6, but on it has been extended to September 12, 2020.

description: In Tonga, a national full lockdown has been declared by Tonga's Prime Minister Pohiva Tu'i'onetoa for one week starting  Sunday March 29th, 2020 at 1:00am and ending Sunday April 5, 2020. Non-essential movement outside of residences will be prohibited. The exception to the isolation order includes purchasing or supplying essential consumer goods, obtaining medical supplies or seeking medical assistance, access to banking and other financial services and attending work as a member of an essential service provider.

In Tonga, a national full lockdown has been declared by Tonga's Prime Minister Pohiva Tu'i'onetoa for one week starting  Sunday March 29th, 2020 at 1:00am and ending Sunday April 5, 2020. Non-essential movement outside of residences will be prohibited. The exception to the isolation order includes purchasing or supplying essential consumer goods, obtaining medical supplies or seeking medical assistance, access to banking and other financial services and attending work as a member of an essential service provider. UPDATE: Renewal of the National Lockdown Notice dated 26 March 2020 to be applied over all the land and seas of Tonga to continue commencing from 1.00am on Sunday 5 April 2020 to 1.00am Sunday 12 April 2020.

The following services have been added to the restrictions: Village market vendors and mobile markets (agriculture and fisheries), Agricultural and Fisheries export activities and inter-island marine transport within the Ha’apai, Vava’u & Niua Islands.

In Tonga, a national full lockdown has been declared by Tonga's Prime Minister Pohiva Tu'i'onetoa for one week starting  Sunday March 29th, 2020 at 1:00am and ending Sunday April 5, 2020. Non-essential movement outside of residences will be prohibited. The exception to the isolation order includes purchasing or supplying essential consumer goods, obtaining medical supplies or seeking medical assistance, access to banking and other financial services and attending work as a member of an essential service provider. UPDATE: The original lockdown was set to last until April 12th 2020, it has been extended to April 17th 2020.

In Tonga, a national full lockdown has been declared by Tonga's Prime Minister Pohiva Tu'i'onetoa for one week starting  Sunday March 29th, 2020 at 1:00am and ending Sunday April 5, 2020. Non-essential movement outside of residences will be prohibited. The exception to the isolation order includes purchasing or supplying essential consumer goods, obtaining medical supplies or seeking medical assistance, access to banking and other financial services and attending work as a member of an essential service provider. UPDATE: The lockdown was set to last until April 17th 2020, it has been extended to April 24th 2020. The previous lockdown protocols have all remained except for a relaxation on the number of people permitted at funerals. The number of people allowed indoors has risen from 10 to 20 and the number outdoors has risen from 20 to 40 people.

UPDATE: The lockdown has been further extended for another a week from April 24th until May 1st 2020.

In Tonga his majesty’s Government has established a COVID-19 task force comprised of key Government Ministries and Chaired by the Hon. Minister for Health, assisted by the Hon. Minister for Meteorology, Energy, Information, Disaster Management, Environment, Climate Change and Communications (MEIDECC); and Hon. Minister for Education and Training (MET) after February 4th, 2020.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: Tonga introduced an economic and social stimulus package to combat COVID 19 on April 2nd, 2020.

The Government of Tonga and the World Bank have provided conditional cash transfers to 1,162 Tongan households at a project launch in the Tongan capital, Nuku’alofa as part of an effort to address the financial constraints many households face in keeping their children in secondary school. Part of the transfer will be an additional one-off payment of TOP200, provided to assist vulnerable Tongan families deal with the economic fallout of the COVID-19 pandemic. The families who received both payments were identified through a nationally run poverty means test.
type_text: cash transfer to parents to assist with financial hardships resulting from COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
The Tonga National Tripartite Committee (TNTC) announced on August 6 that they will conduct a national rapid assessment on the impact CoViD-19 on businesses and employment. The assessment will run from 10 August until 7 September.
TNTC is organizing the survey with support from the International Labour Organization (ILO).
The Ministry of Trade & Economic Development CEO, Distaquaine Tu'ihalamaka said the survey will look at three key areas: how many businesses have been negatively impacted, how many jobs have been or will be impacted, and the type of sector impacted because of CoViD-19.
The tourism sector will be assessed separately.
type_text: Survey to assess CoViD-19 impact on businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Tonga's Ministry of Health announced COVID-19 advice for pregnant and breastfeeding women in a public awareness measure. Pregnant women are advised to avoid all non-essential overseas travel. Pregnant women do not appear to be more susceptible to COVID-19, but caution it advised because they are at high risk of developing severe symptoms if they get COVID-19. There is no evidence that the virus can pass to a baby during pregnancy or an increase risk of miscarriage in relation to COVID-19. There is no evidence that the virus can be carried in breast milk so breast feeding is safe.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Travel Advisory No. 2 For Travelers Arriving In or Intending to Travel to Tonga 
International travellers, travelling through or from China, must spend at least 14 days self-quarantine at last port that is free of COVID-19 and must undergo medical clearance within (3) days prior to final route to Tonga with exceptions for Tongan citizens, permanent residents and their immediate family members and air crew who wore appropriate PPE. 

All international travellers, who have been in China 14 days prior to their arrival in Tonga, are required to report to the Ministry of Health’s Public Health Communicable Disease and Environmental Health Units upon arrival for the purpose of health quarantine measures.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Tonga, a nationwide lockdown has been declared from 29 March to 5 April. Non-essential movement outside of residences will be prohibited. Night-time curfews will be in place from 20.00 to 06.00. Non-essential businesses will be closed and large gatherings will be suspended.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Personal Grooming Businesses (e.g. hair salons)") is closed/locked down

description:
Tonga's National Lockdown which began March 26 2020 has been continued starting 01:00AM April 5 2020 - 01:00AM April 12 2020.

Added to this policy is the restrictions on Village market vendors and mobile markets (Agriculture and fisheries). As well as restrictions on Agricultural and Fisheries export activities. Despite the Lockdown policy as a whole starting on the 5th this restriction on markets will start on the April 4th.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Agriculture; forestry and fishing") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Tonga (under the state of emergency regulations), nightclubs, bars, and kava clubs are shut down after March 25, 2020, until April 17, 2020. UPDATE: As a part of the national lockdown measures, the restrictions on clubs, bars, bingo, gyms and other non-essential businesses have been continued for another week from April 17th - April 24th 2020.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is closed/locked down
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: In Tonga (under the state of emergeny regulations), public gatherings restricted to a maximum of 20 people inside a building or 40 people outside, and people are to practice social distancing. Concerts, sports events, funerals, weddings and birthdays are also banned starting from March 20th, 2020 until April 17th, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of a recreational or commercial event
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: In Tonga a State of Emergency has been announced, effective from 20 March 20.00 to 17 April, unless further renewed. Public gatherings are restricted. Nightclubs, bars and kava clubs shut down from 25 March. Concerts, sports events, funerals, weddings and birthdays are banned.

In Tonga (under the state of emergeny regulations), public gatherings restricted to a maximum of 20 people inside a building or 40 people outside, and people are to practice social distancing. Concerts, sports events, funerals, weddings and birthdays are also banned starting from March 20th, 2020 until April 17th, 2020. UPDATE: The restriction on funerals of maximum 40 people outside and 20 people inside has been strengthened. From April 12th 2020 until April 17th there will be a maximum of 20 people outside and 10 people inside, with an authorised officer present throughout.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of a recreational or commercial event
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: In Tonga (under the state of emergeny regulations), public gatherings restricted to a maximum of 20 people inside a building or 40 people outside, and people are to practice social distancing. Concerts, sports events, funerals, weddings and birthdays are also banned starting from March 20th, 2020 until April 17th, 2020. UPDATE: The restriction on funerals has again been relaxed from the restrictions that started on April 12th 2020. 40 people are allowed outside instead of 20 and 20 people allowed inside instead of 10. The end date has also been extended to April 24th 2020.

description: "'Mass gathering' means any gathering not exceeding a total of 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors in any gatherings except for religious services and education institutions" in Tonga
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
"'Mass gathering' means any gathering not exceeding a total of 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors in any gatherings except for religious services and education institutions" in Tonga.
This restriction has been extended until July 8. UPDATE: The original restriction on funeral gatherings was set to last until June 11, it has been extended until July 8 under the National COVID-19 Restrictions Notice (“Notice”) in the Renewal of the Declaration of a State of Emergency.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
